base_note.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Robert Kowalski
MRN: 6957003
DOB: 11/08/1961 (63 years old)
Date of Service: 2025-04-17
Location: University Medical Center, Phoenix, AZ

Attending Physician: Dr. James Park, MD
Fellow: Dr. Lisa Tran, MD (PGY-6)
RN: Sarah Mitchell, RN
RT: David Chen, RRT

INDICATION: Refractory hepatic hydrothorax in patient with decompensated cirrhosis (Child-Pugh C, MELD 24). Prior TIPS revision unsuccessful. Requiring twice-weekly thoracenteses with significant symptom burden. Not a liver transplant candidate.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right hepatic hydrothorax

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Tunneled indwelling pleural catheter placement, right hemithorax

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation (Midazolam 2mg IV, Fentanyl 75mcg IV) with local anesthesia (1% lidocaine with epinephrine)

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:
Patient positioned in left lateral decubitus. Standard surgical timeout completed confirming right side, procedure, and patient identity. Pre-procedure ultrasound demonstrated large right pleural effusion with no loculations. Optimal entry point identified at 6th intercostal space, posterior axillary line.

The skin was prepped with chlorhexidine and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was administered along the proposed insertion tract and subcutaneous tunnel. A 15mm skin incision was made at the insertion point.

Using the Rocket Medical tunneling system, a 12cm subcutaneous tunnel was created from the insertion site anteriorly toward the anterior axillary line. The Rocket IPC was threaded through the tunnel with the Dacron cuff positioned approximately 2cm from the exit site to promote tissue ingrowth.

The pleural space was accessed using modified Seldinger technique. Real-time ultrasound confirmed the guidewire position in the pleural space. The dilator and peel-away sheath were introduced, and the 15.5Fr Rocket catheter was advanced into the pleural space. The position was confirmed with aspiration of clear, straw-colored fluid.

1,800mL of transudative-appearing fluid was drained. Pleural fluid samples sent for cell count, chemistry, culture, and cytology. The catheter was secured with 2-0 Prolene sutures. Exit site dressed with sterile gauze and Tegaderm.

Post-procedure CXR showed catheter tip in dependent right hemithorax, significant improvement in effusion, no pneumothorax.

FINDINGS:
- Large free-flowing right pleural effusion
- Transudative appearing fluid
- No loculations or septations
- Catheter positioned in posterior dependent space

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: <5mL

DISPOSITION: Admitted for overnight observation given hepatic encephalopathy risk with large volume drainage. Home health arranged for daily drainage (max 1000mL/day).

FOLLOW-UP: Interventional pulmonology clinic in 2 weeks.

Electronically signed by:
James Park, MD
Lisa Tran, MD (Fellow)

code_rationales.32550: Insertion of tunneled indwelling pleural catheter (Rocket) with subcutaneous tunneling for hepatic hydrothorax.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Appropriate code for new IPC insertion. Hepatic hydrothorax is valid indication for tunneled catheter when medical management and TIPS have failed.

cpt_codes.description: Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff

changes: Populated registry_entry.billing from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 for CPT codes 32550; total_work_rvu=3.92, total_rvu=5.88 (facility).

variations.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION AND DEMOGRAPHICS
----------------------------------------
Patient: Gabriel Wood
Medical Record Number: 8541848
Date of Birth: 11/08/1966
Age at Procedure: 59 years
Procedure Date: N/A

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with refractory hepatic hydrothorax. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Ipc:


INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
- Large free-flowing right pleural effusion
- Transudative appearing fluid
- No loculations or septations
- Catheter positioned in posterior dependent space


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

PROCEDURAL CODING DOCUMENTATION
----------------------------------------
Current Procedural Terminology Codes: 32550

This documentation has been prepared in accordance with institutional standards for procedural documentation and coding compliance.

PROCEDURE NOTE

Date: None
Patient: Dylan Martin
MRN: 7803511
Age/Sex: 65yo patient

Attending Physician: [Attending]
Resident/Fellow: [Trainee, PGY-X]

INDICATION:
Refractory hepatic hydrothorax

CONSENT:
Informed consent obtained. Risks, benefits, and alternatives discussed.
Patient verbalized understanding and agreed to proceed.

TIMEOUT:
Performed. Correct patient, procedure, and site confirmed.

SEDATION:
Moderate

PROCEDURE STEPS:
1. Patient positioned and monitored
2. Sedation administered per protocol
3. Topical anesthesia applied to airway
4. Ipc performed
5. Scope withdrawn
6. Patient recovered without complication

SPECIMENS:
As documented above

COMPLICATIONS:
None

EBL:
Minimal

DISPOSITION:
Inpatient admission

CPT CODES: 32550

ATTESTATION:
I was present for the entire procedure and agree with the above documentation.
[Attending Signature]

variations.note_text:
On None, Jessica Watson, a 63-year-old patient (MRN 1440741), underwent bronchoscopic evaluation for Refractory hepatic hydrothorax. The patient received Moderate and the procedure was performed in standard fashion. The procedure included ipc. 

On examination, the airways were systematically inspected. The procedure was completed without immediate complications. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Specimens obtained were sent for appropriate analysis and results will be reviewed at follow-up. The preliminary assessment is non-malignant. 

Procedural coding: 32550.
